Archivist at The Danish National Archives (Rigsarkivet)

person.bibl: Íslenzkar æviskrár IV, pp. 105-106 [Páll Ámundason yngsti]

person.birth: The middle of the sixteenth century

person.note: A Halldór Jónsson signed a note in AM 170 fol. certifying the ownership of Þorleifur Kláusson. It is uncertain, whether this Halldór Jónsson is identical with the priest Halldór Jónsson, but the priest and Þorleifur both were residents at Skálholt at the same time, and therefore, undoubtedly, were acquainted.
Possibly the correspondent Halthorus Jonæus (AM 1058 4to V).

person.occupation: High Court judge, Titular Councillor of State (Etatsråd)
Lord of Oddenstrup and Fritsø, lensmand of Bratsberg

person.note: AM 63 8vo: When seventeen years old, Magnús was living at his parents' farm, Bassastaðir, in Strandasýsla. Árni Magnússon acquired the manuscript after Magnús' death, so he must have passed it on some time before 1730.
One of the two scribes of Flateyarbók

place.location: Junction of Park Street and Charlotte Street
one mile north west of Bethel New York

placeState.p: Part of the kingdom of Denmark

placeTrait.p: Area is created as Waterloo County

placeEvent.p: Reorganisation from County to Regional Municipality

placeEvent.label: Change of Name
placeEvent.p: In 1916 as a result of the first world war, and given the large percentage of people of German background living in Canada's German capital, it was decided by ballot to change the name from Berlin to Kitchener after Lord Kitchener. Although Berlin's population ridiculed the proposed name change and refused to vote. Although it had a populate of well over 15,000 only 892 people voted. The name Kitchener with 346 votes won by 81 votes. Many Berliners supported maintaining the name of the city, as it reflected a proud tradition of growth and prosperity for German, and non-German, Canadians alike. Those citizens who supported the status quo were immediately perceived, by those who wanted change, as being unpatriotic and sympathizers with the enemy. Violence, riots and intimidation, often instigated by imperialistic members of the 118th Battalion, were not uncommon in the months leading up to the May 1916 referendum on the issue. See What’s In a Name? Berlin to Kitchener

place.note: Kitchener-Waterloo (K-W) is an unofficial but ubiquitous name for the area in Ontario, Canada consisting of the twin cities of Kitchener and Waterloo, approximately 100 kilometres west of Toronto. The two cities grew into each other decades ago and their shared boundary cuts through streets, backyards and houses. While the term is used by local residents, Kitchener and Waterloo are separate cities and not a single municipal entity.

placeState.p: There is no way to give a general prose description about the place as such. I solved it someway here, but I think we talked about a p or note element as one direct child of place. Or is this the locale element?

place.placeName: PalestineThis name is used partly overlapping with , but it is used for another, not existing political entity. Maybe it's not the same place at all?

placeState.p: Administratively the city (and the region) belongs to the Polish kingdom.
Administratively the city (and the region) belongs to Bohemia.
Administratively the city (and the region) belongs to the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
Administratively the city (and the region) belongs to Prussia, later to the German Reich.
Administratively the city (and the region) belongs to the Republic of Poland.

placeEvent.label: Popular Culture
placeEvent.p: There are five larger rivers flowing through the city, and the huge number of bridges of various type (around 200) in the city leads to various associations with other places in Europe like that, for example Venice, Amsterdam, or St. Petersburg.

div.head: Text part
div.p: Zion (Hebrew: צִיּוֹן, tziyyon; Tiberian vocalization: tsiyyôn; transliterated Zion or Sion) is a term that most often designates the land of Israel and its capital Jerusalem. The word is found in texts dating back almost three millennia. It originally referred to a specific mountain near Jerusalem (Mount Zion), on which stood a Jebusite fortress of the same name that was conquered by David and renamed the City of David.
